subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: New Thoughts about Read's Alphabets-2
msgSnippet: I had another thought I would like to clarify about the uh problem in kom.  I realize that I did and still have a preference for certain letters and find
messageBody:
I had another thought I would like to clarify about the "uh" problem in kom.  I realize that I did and still have a preference for certain letters and find them more readable.  For example, I really like the "h" in the Shaw's alphabet compared to the "h" in QS which some careless writers may not give full attention to the hook.  In any case, it does not have the fluidity of the Shaw's "h."  That is, of course, an opinion but I did have to really "fight" in my mind about the utility of using it.  I realize it was probably changed because it could be confused with a "b" in QS or an "m."  And, I think that one has to think about that when creating a script that is highly readable even when the writer is not exactly concerned about readability.

Shorthand however, demands this preciseness whereas one can get away with a bit of thready lettering mostly due to our familiarity with the context and word from repeated reading and writing compared to Read's alphabet.  The English language would have to be compulsively standardized to get a closer familiarity on scribbled words I should think.

I watch Aljazeera on t.v. and there are people in the Phillippines, India, and other areas in which international English pronunciation is not well-known at all.  And, i have given up on some Australians whose dialect is way over my head -- unfortunately --- as I was eager to be companionable with them.  The answer of course, would be to teach children two pronunciations of the English language -- their own and the international pronunciation.  I have heard some beautiful sounding English words that are clear as a bell but it has not become an essential diplomat's focus when I watch international programs.  Is there someone out there who could.......

Many thanks for the patience of those who read this.

Sid


--- On Fri, 8/19/11, Sid Tanaban <sidban2@...> wrote:

From: Sid Tanaban <sidban2@...>
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: New Thoughts about Read's Alphabets
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Date: Friday, August 19, 2011, 8:42 PM

 

Hi again,
I didn't realize the extent of thought others had on this.  I have now been thinking about using both Shaw's alphabet letters and QS in my own modified script of "Read's alphabets."

Some ideas that I got from other writers is that it is more cursive but cursive script has a tendency to break down when written fast anyway.  That is why the schools are teaching more of a print script.  We can also see this with Pitman and Gregg.  Unless the writer is very obsessive about shaping letters proportionally and using correct spacing between letters, words, lines, etc., there is not much to recommend cursive over print.  Print clearly is easier to read.

Secondly, any shorthand writer will develop their own way of abbreviating words.  It is difficult at times for another writer to read a modified script.  If QS and Shaw's alphabet is a shorthand of some kind, then alphabet shorthand would definitely be faster and easier to read.  On the other hand, how can QS or Shaw's alphabet compete with Greg or Pitman?

Thirdly, I had a deuce of a time learning both scripts.  The problem with Shaw's alphabet was the British accent - my accent is midwestern U.S.  Writing the scripts were easier for me than reading.  One might be curious to know that I speak a new language easier than understand it which is very difficult for me.

Anyway, I would ask this question of myself and whoever else wants to answer it:  What really is the purpose of Read's alphabets?  Shaw wanted a phonetic alphabet and more abbreviated so he could fit more letters on a page.  However, my sense was that the more abbreviated strokes often make one hesitate unless one is either accustomed to it or can take slight alterations of the letter in stride.

For example, the "uh" in kom in the QS could suffer from readability if written quickly in a cursive link.  The pause for readability would prevent fluid readability that would not be the case with an alphabet shorthand since we are more accustomed to the latin letters which are a bit more elaborated.

Frankly, I began to think of the alphabets as more of a secret code such as I use to get from old-time radio programs as Capt. Midnight, Jack Armstrong, etc.  I use it to write down what I would not want anyone else to read or know about which is really not often.

My own experience in correspondence was that it was brief.  I wrote to a man in New Zealand for awhile but unless one has a particular common interest in some matter the correspondence begins to wear thin after awhile.  

The last point about not being a purist about Read's alphabets is that others -- I believe it was Mr. Page, was it not? who developed a revised version of Read's alphabet which I was tempted to send for.  And, I have noticed even in Esperanto that "x" I believe became a "ch" character that Zamenhoff did not create at the time it became popular.  My point here is that human nature likes to tinker with such matters -- languages change, alphabets get altered, etc.  

It might be if there is enough interest that some people will get together and in some way try to integrate both Shaw's alphabet and QS or accept a further revision of Read's work.  I don't think it would be a heresy to take an interest in the advantages, if any, in adopting a more practical or aesthetic approach.   The point here of my own interest is whether his language creations have benefits that have not been thoroughly covered

Sid

--- On Fri, 8/19/11, Sid Tanaban <sidban2@...> wrote:

From: Sid Tanaban <sidban2@...>
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: I'd like to be able to write the prefixes com- and con- as contractions
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Date: Friday, August 19, 2011, 8:04 PM

 

Mr. Read was quite willing to abandon the Shaw's alphabet and use other letters that he thought more suitable.  It was his opinion -- not a scientific rule!  My opinion would be if you do not like "o" then use the "uh" of Shaw's alphabet.  Actually, I recognize that very easily.  I studied Shaw's alphabet before QS and think some of the letters are much more aesthetically drawn.  And, that would be my viewpoint about other questions about such a matter.  Mr. Read may or may not have been dogmatic about what he created but it is really preferable for your own use to choose what is delightful and easy to read.  After all, do you want to view this as one would view the Bible?  The script is only a tool for one's own pleasure and surely a minor change is not going to harm readability, particularly when everyone is sounding out these words according to their own particular use of English anyway.

I am sure someone will object to what I have to say and I would be curious if someone feels that there is something I have overlooked.  If so, please convey your thought on it.
Sid

--- On Fri, 8/19/11, cossyrosario <cossyrosario@...> wrote:

From: cossyrosario <cossyrosario@...>
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: I'd like to be able to write the prefixes com- and con- as contractions
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Date: Friday, August 19, 2011, 12:28 PM

 

What is T.O.?
Traditional Orthodox? (equivalent to Latin letters?)

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "C. Paige Gabhart" <pgabhart@...>
wrote:
>
>
>
> I would recommend against using an "o" even for a private
"work-around"
> when that is not the sound needed for the word. In my opinion, you
want
> to indelibly link the QS letters with the sounds they represent in
your
> mind to foster automatic reading, i.e. without the necessity of
sounding
> out words. After all, this is what we do with T.O.
>
> I think the use of a letter that represents a different sound in place
> of the correct letter, would be counter productive and harmful to your
> comprehension. I would just advise you to realize that QS does not
> require that every letter be joined to every other letter. QS is
quite
> cursive as Read designed it. The small amount of time required for
the
> occasional pen-lift, is not worth the confusion of muddying the
phonemic
> character, might I say, "purity," of the alphabet.
>
> Just my two cents.
>
>
> Paige Gabhart
>
>
> On 8/18/2011 12:12 PM, cossyrosario wrote:
> >
> > Thanks, Sid.
> >
> > The reason why I didn't use this work-around is because I've been
> > trying to follow the QuikScript rule that the letters represent
> > /sounds/ of the English language.
> >
> > In com- con- the o sound is like the u in utter (as in commend,
> > contend), or like the o in ox (compliment, conscious). The o when
> > written as in Latin letters (as a circle) has the sound of owe in
owe.
> > Therefore com- with the circle o would rhyme with comb, and con-
with
> > the circle o would rhyme with cone, which is not what I want to.
> >
> > However, if I were making notes for myself, as is the case most of
the
> > time I use QuikScript, I could certainly use the o as a private
> > work-around.
> >
> > What I have been using as an even shorter work-around for temporary
> > private notes (to-do list, notes of a meeting discussion to be
> > transcribed fairly soon on the computer) is just the k as a prefix,
> > thus kputer for computer, kshus for conscious, etc.
> >
> >
> > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Sid Tanaban sidban2@ wrote:
> > >
> > > com or con can be written in one stroke. Â Just write the "o"
as you
> > would in latin letters and add the "m" Â Unfortunately, I have
no
> > idea how to do this on a computer.
> > > Sid
> > >
> > > --- On Wed, 8/17/11, cossyrosario cossyrosario@ wrote:
> > >

> > > Date: Wednesday, August 17, 2011, 11:20 PM
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > Thank you, Steve!
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > In my hurry to learn as much as possible as soon as possible, I
raced
> > >
> > > through the manual, and must have raced past the section on com-
con- as
> > >
> > > it must have seemed obvious, with nothing new to learn! Or so it
must
> > >
> > > have seemed at the time.
> > >

t] Re: I'd like to be able to write the prefixes com- and con- as contracti=
ons
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Date: Friday, August 19, 2011, 8:04 P=
M















 
=C2=A0



    
      
      
      Mr. Read was quite wi=
lling to abandon the Shaw's alphabet and use other letters that he thought =
more suitable. =C2=A0It was his opinion -- not a scientific rule! =C2=A0My =
opinion would be if you do not like "o" then use the "uh" of Shaw's alphabe=
t. =C2=A0Actually, I recognize that very easily. =C2=A0I studied Shaw's alp=
habet before QS and think some of the letters are much more aesthetically d=
rawn. =C2=A0And, that would be my viewpoint about other questions about suc=
h a matter. =C2=A0Mr. Read may or may not have been dogmatic about what he =
created but it is really preferable for your own use to choose what is deli=
ghtful and easy to read. =C2=A0After all, do you want to view this as one w=
ould view the Bible? =C2=A0The script is only a tool for one's own pleasure=
 and surely a minor change is not going to harm readability, particularly w=
hen everyone
 is sounding
 out these words according to their own particula=
r use of English anyway.
I am sure someone will object to what I have to sa=
y and I would be curious if someone feels that there is something I have ov=
erlooked. =C2=A0If so, please convey your thought on it.Sid

wrote:

>

>

>

> I would recommend against using an=
 "o" even for a private

"work-around"

> when that is not the sound needed=
 for the word.  In my opinion, you

want

> to indelibly link the QS letter=
s with the sounds they represent in

your

> mind to foster automatic readi=
ng, i.e. without the necessity of

sounding

> out words.  After all, this =
is what we do with T.O.

>

> I think the use of a letter that represents a=
 different sound in place

> of the correct letter, would be counter produc=
tive and harmful to your

> comprehension.  I would just advise you to real=
ize that QS does not

> require that every letter be joined to every other =
letter.  QS is

quite

> cursive as Read designed it.  The small amount of =
time required for

the

> occasional pen-lift, is not worth the confusion o=
f muddying the

phonemic

> character, might I say, "purity," of the alphab=
et.

>

> Just my two cents.

>

>

> Paige Gabhart

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

<table cellspacing=3D"0" cellpadding=3D"0" border=3D"0" ><tr><td valign=3D"=
top" style=3D"font: inherit;">I had another thought I would like to clarify=
 about the "uh" problem in kom.  I realize that I did and still have a=
 preference for certain letters and find them more readable.  For exam=
ple, I really like the "h" in the Shaw's alphabet compared to the "h" in QS=
 which some careless writers may not give full attention to the hook. &nbsp=
;In any case, it does not have the fluidity of the Shaw's "h."  That i=
s, of course, an opinion but I did have to really "fight" in my mind about =
the utility of using it.  I realize it was probably changed because it=
 could be confused with a "b" in QS or an "m."  And, I think that one =
has to think about that when creating a script that is highly readable even=
 when the writer is not exactly concerned about readability.<div><br></div>=
<div>Shorthand however, demands this preciseness whereas one can get away w=
ith
 a bit of thready lettering mostly due to our familiarity with the cont=
ext and word from repeated reading and writing compared to Read's alphabet.=
  The English language would have to be compulsively standardized to g=
et a closer familiarity on scribbled words I should think.</div><div><br></=
div><div>I watch Aljazeera on t.v. and there are people in the Phillippines=
, India, and other areas in which international English pronunciation is no=
t well-known at all.  And, i have given up on some Australians whose d=
ialect is way over my head -- unfortunately --- as I was eager to be compan=
ionable with them.  The answer of course, would be to teach children t=
wo pronunciations of the English language -- their own and the internationa=
l pronunciation.  I have heard some beautiful sounding English words t=
hat are clear as a bell but it has not become an essential diplomat's focus=
 when I watch international programs.  Is there someone out there
 who=
 could.......</div><div><br></div><div>Many thanks for the patience of thos=
e who read this.</div><div><br></div><div>Sid</div><div><div><div><br><br>-=
-- On <b>Fri, 8/19/11, Sid Tanaban <i><sidban2@...></i></b> wro=
te:<br><blockquote style=3D"border-left: 2px solid rgb(16, 16, 255); margin=
-left: 5px; padding-left: 5px;"><br>From: Sid Tanaban <sidban2@...=
><br>Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: New Thoughts about Read's Alphabet=
s<br>To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com<br>Date: Friday, August 19, 2011, 8:=
42 PM<br><br><div id=3D"yiv860747502">













 
<span style=3D"displa=
y:none;"> </span>



    <div id=3D"yiv860747502ygrp-text">
      
   =
   
      <p><table cellspacing=3D"0" cellpadding=3D"0" border=3D"0"><tbody=
><tr><td valign=3D"top" style=3D"font:inherit;">Hi again,<div>I didn't real=
ize the extent of thought others had on this.  I have now been thinkin=
g about using both Shaw's alphabet letters and QS in my own modified script=
 of "Read's alphabets."</div><div><br></div><div>Some ideas that I got from=
 other writers is that it is more cursive but cursive script has a tendency=
 to break down when written fast anyway.  That is why the schools are =
teaching more of a print script.  We can also see this with Pitman and=
 Gregg.  Unless the writer is very obsessive about shaping letters pro=
portionally and using correct spacing between letters, words, lines, etc., =
there is not much to recommend cursive over print.  Print clearly is e=
asier to read.</div><div><br></div><div>Secondly, any shorthand writer will=
 develop their own way of abbreviating words.  It is difficult at time=
s for
 another writer
 to read a modified script.  If QS and Shaw's al=
phabet is a shorthand of some kind, then alphabet shorthand would definitel=
y be faster and easier to read.  On the other hand, how can QS or Shaw=
's alphabet compete with Greg or Pitman?</div><div><br></div><div>Thirdly, =
I had a deuce of a time learning both scripts.  The problem with Shaw'=
s alphabet was the British accent - my accent is midwestern U.S.  Writ=
ing the scripts were easier for me than reading.  One might be curious=
 to know that I speak a new language easier than understand it which is ver=
y difficult for me.</div><div><br></div><div>Anyway, I would ask this quest=
ion of myself and whoever else wants to answer it:  What really is the=
 purpose of Read's alphabets?  Shaw wanted a phonetic alphabet and mor=
e abbreviated so he could fit more letters on a page.  However, my sen=
se was that the more abbreviated strokes often make one hesitate unless one=
 is either
 accustomed to it or can take slight alterations of the letter i=
n stride.</div><div><br></div><div>For example, the "uh" in kom in the QS c=
ould suffer from readability if written quickly in a cursive link.  Th=
e pause for readability would prevent fluid readability that would not be t=
he case with an alphabet shorthand since we are more accustomed to the lati=
n letters which are a bit more elaborated.</div><div><br></div><div>Frankly=
, I began to think of the alphabets as more of a secret code such as I use =
to get from old-time radio programs as Capt. Midnight, Jack Armstrong, etc.=
  I use it to write down what I would not want anyone else to read or =
know about which is really not often.</div><div><br></div><div>My own exper=
ience in correspondence was that it was brief.  I wrote to a man in Ne=
w Zealand for awhile but unless one has a particular common interest in som=
e matter the correspondence begins to wear thin after awhile.
  </div>=
<div><br></div><div>The last point about not being a purist about Read's al=
phabets is that others -- I believe it was Mr. Page, was it not? who develo=
ped a revised version of Read's alphabet which I was tempted to send for. &=
nbsp;And, I have noticed even in Esperanto that "x" I believe became a "ch"=
 character that Zamenhoff did not create at the time it became popular. &nb=
sp;My point here is that human nature likes to tinker with such matters -- =
languages change, alphabets get altered, etc.  </div><div><br></div><d=
iv>It might be if there is enough interest that some people will get togeth=
er and in some way try to integrate both Shaw's alphabet and QS or accept a=
 further revision of Read's work.  I don't think it would be a heresy =
to take an interest in the advantages, if any, in adopting a more practical=
 or aesthetic approach.   The point here of my own interest is whether=
 his language creations have benefits that have not
 been thoroughly covere=
d</div><div><br></div><div>Sid<br><br>--- On <b>Fri, 8/19/11, Sid Tanaban <=
i><sidban2@...></i></b> wrote:<br><blockquote style=3D"border-l=
eft:2px solid rgb(16, 16, 255);"><br>From: Sid Tanaban <sidban2@...=
m><br>Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: I'd like to be able to write the =
prefixes com- and con- as contractions<br>To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com=
<br>Date: Friday, August 19, 2011, 8:04 PM<br><br><div id=3D"yiv860747502">=














 
<span> </span>



    <div id=3D"yiv860747502ygrp-text=
">
      
      
      <p><table cellspacing=3D"0" cellpadding=3D"0" border=
=3D"0"><tbody><tr><td valign=3D"top" style=3D"font:inherit;">Mr. Read was q=
uite willing to abandon the Shaw's alphabet and use other letters that he t=
hought more suitable.  It was his opinion -- not a scientific rule! &n=
bsp;My opinion would be if you do not like "o" then use the "uh" of Shaw's =
alphabet.  Actually, I recognize that very easily.  I studied Sha=
w's alphabet before QS and think some of the letters are much more aestheti=
cally drawn.  And, that would be my viewpoint about other questions ab=
out such a matter.  Mr. Read may or may not have been dogmatic about w=
hat he created but it is really preferable for your own use to choose what =
is delightful and easy to read.  After all, do you want to view this a=
s one would view the Bible?  The script is only a tool for one's own p=
leasure and surely a minor change is not going to harm readability, particu=
larly when everyone
 is sounding
 out these words according to their own pa=
rticular use of English anyway.<div><br></div><div>I am sure someone will o=
bject to what I have to say and I would be curious if someone feels that th=
ere is something I have overlooked.  If so, please convey your thought=
 on it.</div><div>Sid<br><br>--- On <b>Fri, 8/19/11, cossyrosario <i><co=
ssyrosario@...></i></b> wrote:<br><blockquote style=3D"border-le=
ft:2px solid rgb(16, 16, 255);"><br>From: cossyrosario <cossyrosario@yah=
oo.co.in><br>Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: I'd like to be able to write t=
he prefixes com- and con- as contractions<br>To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.=
com<br>Date: Friday, August 19, 2011, 12:28 PM<br><br><div id=3D"yiv8607475=
02">
